s.text: Already, the idea of the black reference book with glamorous editors is something of a real problem and should make the public a bit suspicious because it seems so much like a marketing ploy.

I like Appiah, too, and think him very smart.
I think Gates particularly is a very smart guy and a good writer, if he were to give himself the time to write the way he can.

It is, perhaps, this sense of opportunism, and of blowing up ordinary jobs like creating a black reference book of this sort as if one were announcing the return of the monarchy to America, that makes you feel uneasy about many of the black public intellectuals.
My bottom line is that I would recommend the book to students and colleagues and I hope it does well, despite its anti-intellectual p.c.

West's essay on Du Bois in Africana seemed a re-working of his essay on Du Bois in The Future of the Race . There is nothing new said in his Africana essay, and his presentism, his insistence on judging a historical figure by current moral standards, I find fatuous, just poor scholarship.
Living With It, Warts and All
There is far too much Gates and West and there is far too little in what they are saying to justify their demand for your attention or for the culture's attention.

This is a fair question.
This is a fair question.

Some of the compromises are the normal sorts of difficulties that all intellectuals face--from over-edited writing meant to make easy any difficult idea to the need for excessive conflict in order to make the work "interesting."
What is curious about Africana is that they both--Gates and Appiah--are doing a book that I think, in its current manifestation, is beneath them.

Plus, he has won a major literary prize, something that means a lot to the people who put together this book.
Africana is making a statement about what the editors and the advisory board feel is important.
